name: J-Pop
description: Commercial Pop of Japan after the advent of the Heisei era (1989), characterized by modernized production, a more eclectic sound palette, and a more westernized vocal style.

children.name: Akishibu-kei
children.description: Otaku inclined update of the style pioneered by the Shibuya-kei scene, mixed with J-Pop and often tied to Anime and Video Game Music.

children.name: Akishibu-kei
children.description: Otaku inclined update of the style pioneered by the Shibuya-kei scene, mixed with J-Pop and often tied to Anime and Video Game Music.

children.name: Denpa
children.description: Underground style aiming to be bizarre yet catchy, using off-key and high-pitched vocals, strange or nonsensical lyrics, repetitive chants, onomatopoeia, frantic and "off-kilter" production, and "moe" aesthetics.

children.name: Denpa
children.description: Underground style aiming to be bizarre yet catchy, using off-key and high-pitched vocals, strange or nonsensical lyrics, repetitive chants, onomatopoeia, frantic and "off-kilter" production, and "moe" aesthetics.

children.name: Wa Euro
children.description: Traditional form of J-Pop that emerged in the second half of the 1980s from late Hi-NRG, '80s British Dance-Pop and Italo-Disco/Eurobeat.

children.name: Wa Euro
children.description: Traditional form of J-Pop that emerged in the second half of the 1980s from late Hi-NRG, '80s British Dance-Pop and Italo-Disco/Eurobeat.

children.name: Yakousei
children.description: Eclectic style of J-Pop developed in the late 2010s and influenced by the Vocaloid Scene; incorporates indie sensibilities, danceable rhythms and a focus on introspective lyricism.
